Elijah 'Lije' Baley.description: A plain-clothes detective with a long, dour face and intensely brown eyes.
Elijah 'Lije' Baley.personality: Irritable, pragmatic, and somewhat resistant to change, especially regarding robots.
Elijah 'Lije' Baley.role: Protagonist and detective tasked with solving a murder case involving Spacers.

R. Sammy.description: A robot assigned to perform duties in the police department.
R. Sammy.personality: Obedient but lacks human intuition and understanding.
R. Sammy.role: A robot messenger in the police department.

Julius Enderby.description: Commissioner of Police, wears spectacles due to sensitive eyes.
Julius Enderby.personality: Nervous, somewhat sentimental, and values appearances.
Julius Enderby.role: Baley's superior and friend, who assigns him the murder case.

Simpson.description: A colleague of Baley, works with merc-pool files.
Simpson.role: A colleague in the police department.

Vince Barrett.description: A young man who lost his job to a robot.
Vince Barrett.personality: Desperate and struggling after losing his job.
Vince Barrett.role: A former employee of the department, now working on yeast farms.

Roj Nemennuh Sarton.personality: Not much is revealed about his personality.
Roj Nemennuh Sarton.role: The murder victim whose case Baley is assigned to solve.

R. Daneel Olivaw.description: A robot assigned as Baley's partner.
R. Daneel Olivaw.personality: Not described in this excerpt, but implied to be highly advanced.
R. Daneel Olivaw.role: Baley's robot partner in the murder investigation.

dialogues.speaker: R. Sammy
dialogues.text: The boss wants you, Lije. Right away. Soon as you come in.
dialogues.context: R. Sammy informs Baley that the Commissioner wants to see him.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: All right. I said, all right. Go away!
dialogues.context: Baley responds irritably to R. Sammy's message.

dialogues.speaker: Simpson
dialogues.text: Boss wants you, Lije.
dialogues.context: Simpson reiterates the message from R. Sammy as Baley passes by.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: I know. R. Sammy told me.
dialogues.context: Baley acknowledges Simpson's message.

dialogues.speaker: Simpson
dialogues.text: I’d kick R. Sammy’s behind if I weren’t afraid I’d break a leg. I saw Vince Barrett the other day.
dialogues.context: Simpson jokes about R. Sammy and mentions seeing Vince Barrett.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Oh?
dialogues.context: Baley responds to Simpson's mention of Vince Barrett.

dialogues.speaker: Simpson
dialogues.text: He was looking for his job back. Or any job in the Department. The poor kid’s desperate, but what could I tell him. R. Sammy’s doing his job and that’s all. The kid has to work a delivery tread on the yeast farms now. He was a bright boy, too. Everyone liked him.
dialogues.context: Simpson explains Vince Barrett's situation after losing his job.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: It’s a thing we’re all living through.
dialogues.context: Baley comments on the situation of job loss due to robots.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Sit down, Lije. Sit down.
dialogues.context: Enderby invites Baley to sit down in his office.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: How’s Jessie? And the boy?
dialogues.context: Enderby inquires about Baley's family.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Fine. Just fine. And your family?
dialogues.context: Baley responds to Enderby's inquiry about his family.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Fine. Just fine.
dialogues.context: Enderby echoes Baley's response about his own family.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Commissioner, I wish you wouldn’t send R. Sammy out after me.
dialogues.context: Baley expresses discomfort with R. Sammy delivering messages.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Well, you know how I feel about those things, Lije. But he’s been put here and I’ve got to use him for something.
dialogues.context: Enderby explains his position on using R. Sammy.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: It’s uncomfortable, Commissioner. He tells me you want me and then he stands there. You know what I mean. I have to tell him to go or he just keeps on standing there.
dialogues.context: Baley describes the awkwardness of interacting with R. Sammy.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s my fault, Lije. I gave him the message to deliver and forgot to tell him specifically to get back to his job when he was through.
dialogues.context: Enderby admits to forgetting to give R. Sammy complete instructions.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Anyway, you wanted to see me.
dialogues.context: Baley prompts Enderby to discuss the reason for their meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Yes, Lije, but not for anything easy.
dialogues.context: Enderby indicates that the discussion will be about a difficult matter.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: I had this arranged specially last year, Lije. I don’t think I’ve showed it to you before. Come over here and take a look. In the old days, all rooms had things like this. They were called 'windows.' Did you know that?
dialogues.context: Enderby shows Baley a window and discusses its historical significance.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: I’ve heard of them.
dialogues.context: Baley acknowledges his knowledge of windows from historical novels.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Come here.
dialogues.context: Enderby invites Baley to look through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Pardon me, Commissioner, but you’re wearing new glasses, aren’t you?
dialogues.context: Baley notices something different about Enderby and asks about his glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Yes. I broke my old ones three days ago. What with one thing or another I wasn’t able to replace them till this morning. Lije, those three days were hell.
dialogues.context: Enderby explains the situation with his glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: On account of the glasses?
dialogues.context: Baley questions if the glasses were the sole reason for Enderby's distress.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: And other things, too. I’m getting to that.
dialogues.context: Enderby hints at additional issues beyond the glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: This is the third time this month I’ve watched it rain. Quite a sight, don’t you think?
dialogues.context: Enderby comments on the rarity and spectacle of rain.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: It always seems a waste for all that water to come down on the city. It should restrict itself to the reservoirs.
dialogues.context: Baley expresses a practical view on rain.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Lije, you’re a modernist. That’s your trouble. In Medieval times, people lived in the open. I don’t mean on the farms only. I mean in the cities, too. Even in New York. When it rained, they didn’t think of it as waste. They gloried in it. They lived close to nature. It’s healthier, better. The troubles of modern life come from being divorced from nature. Read up on the Coal Century, sometimes.
dialogues.context: Enderby shares his views on modern life and historical living.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Look, Julius, you’re talking about everything except what I came in here for, and it’s worrying me. What is it?
dialogues.context: Baley urges Enderby to address the main issue.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: I’ll get to it, Lije. Let me do it my way. It’s – it’s trouble.
dialogues.context: Enderby admits to the seriousness of the matter at hand.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Sure. What isn’t on this planet? More trouble with the R’s?
dialogues.context: Baley speculates about the nature of the trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: In a way, yes, Lije. I stand here and wonder how much more trouble the old world can take. When I put in this window, I wasn’t just letting in the sky once in a while. I let in the City. I look at it and I wonder what will become of it in another century.
dialogues.context: Enderby reflects on the future of the world and the city.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: I know what Spacetown is like.
dialogues.context: Baley acknowledges his familiarity with Spacetown.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: I like the picture from here. It can just be made out in the gap between the two Brunswick Sectors. Low domes spread out. It’s the difference between us and the Spacers. We reach high and crowd close. With them, each family has a dome for itself. One family: one house. And land between each dome. Have you ever spoken to any of the Spacers, Lije?
dialogues.context: Enderby contrasts the living conditions of Earthmen and Spacers.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: A few times. About a month ago, I spoke to one right here on your intercom.
dialogues.context: Baley recalls a recent interaction with a Spacer.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Yes, I remember. But then I’m getting philosophical. We and they. Different ways of life.
dialogues.context: Enderby muses on the cultural differences between Earthmen and Spacers.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: All right. But what’s so surprising about it? You can’t spread eight million people over Earth in little domes. They’ve got space on their worlds, so let them live their way.
dialogues.context: Baley argues for the practicality of different living arrangements.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Not everyone is that tolerant about differences in culture. Either among us or among the Spacers.
dialogues.context: Enderby points out the lack of cultural tolerance.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: So three days ago, a Spacer died.
dialogues.context: Baley learns about the murder of a Spacer.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: He died of a missing chest. Someone had used a blaster on him.
dialogues.context: Enderby reveals the cause of the Spacer's death.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?
dialogues.context: Baley is shocked by the revelation of murder.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: I’m talking about murder. You’re a plain-clothes man. You know what murder is.
dialogues.context: Enderby confirms the murder and Baley's role as a detective.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: But a Spacer! Three days ago?
dialogues.context: Baley questions the timing and victim of the murder.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Yes.
dialogues.context: Enderby confirms the details of the murder.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: But who did it? How?
dialogues.context: Baley seeks more information about the murder.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: The Spacers say it was an Earthman.
dialogues.context: Enderby shares the Spacers' accusation.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: It can’t be.
dialogues.context: Baley expresses disbelief at the accusation.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Why not? You don’t like the Spacers. I don’t. Who on Earth does? Someone didn’t like them a little too much, that’s all.
dialogues.context: Enderby suggests a motive for the murder.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Sure, but—
dialogues.context: Baley begins to argue against the accusation.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: There was the fire at the Los Angeles factories. There was the Berlin R-smashing. There were the riots in Shanghai.
dialogues.context: Enderby lists recent events indicating rising tensions.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: All right.
dialogues.context: Baley acknowledges the context of unrest.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: It all points to rising discontent. Maybe to some sort of organization.
dialogues.context: Enderby suggests the possibility of organized resistance.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Commissioner, I don’t get this. Are you testing me for some reason?
dialogues.context: Baley questions the purpose of the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: What?
dialogues.context: Enderby is confused by Baley's question.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Three days ago a Spacer was murdered and the Spacers think the murderer is an Earthman. Till now, nothing’s come out. Is that right? Commissioner, that’s unbelievable. Jehoshaphat, Commissioner, a thing like this would blow New York off the face of the planet if it really happened.
dialogues.context: Baley expresses disbelief at the lack of public knowledge about the murder.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: It’s not as simple as that. Look, Lije, I’ve been out three days. I’ve been in conference with the Mayor. I’ve been out to Spacetown. I’ve been down in Washington, talking to the Terrestrial Bureau of Investigation.
dialogues.context: Enderby explains his actions following the murder.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Oh? And what do the Terries have to say?
dialogues.context: Baley inquires about the Terrestrial Bureau of Investigation's stance.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: They say it’s our baby. It’s inside city limits. Spacetown is under New York jurisdiction.
dialogues.context: Enderby explains the jurisdictional responsibility for the case.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: But with extraterritorial rights.
dialogues.context: Baley points out the complexity of the jurisdiction.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: I know. I’m coming to that.
dialogues.context: Enderby acknowledges the complexity and continues.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: The Spacers can run the show.
dialogues.context: Enderby acknowledges the Spacers' potential control over the investigation.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, Lije. Don’t rush me. I’m trying to talk this over, friend to friend. I want you to know my position. I was there when the news broke. I had an appointment with him – with Roj Nemennuh Sarton.
dialogues.context: Enderby shares his personal involvement with the case.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: The victim?
dialogues.context: Baley confirms the identity of the murder victim.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: The victim.
dialogues.context: Enderby confirms the victim's identity.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Five minutes more and I, myself, would have discovered the body. What a shock that would have been. As it was, it was brutal, brutal. They met me and told me. It started a three-day nightmare, Lije. That on top of having everything blur on me and having no time to replace my glasses for days. That won’t happen again, at least. I’ve ordered three pairs.
dialogues.context: Enderby recounts the events surrounding the discovery of the murder.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: The Spacers have extraterritorial rights. They can insist on their own investigation, make whatever report they wish to their home governments. The Outer Worlds could use this as an excuse to pile on indemnity charges. You know how that would sit with the population.
dialogues.context: Baley discusses the potential political implications of the murder.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: It would be political suicide for the White House to agree to pay.
dialogues.context: Enderby comments on the political consequences of paying indemnity charges.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: And another kind of suicide not to pay.
dialogues.context: Baley acknowledges the dilemma of paying or not paying.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: You don’t have to draw me a picture. Then you see. Pay or not pay, it’s trouble. The only way out is to find the murderer on our own and hand him over to the Spacers. It’s up to us.
dialogues.context: Enderby emphasizes the importance of solving the case.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Why not give it to the TBI? Even if it is our jurisdiction from a legalistic viewpoint, there’s the question of interstellar relations—
dialogues.context: Baley suggests involving the Terrestrial Bureau of Investigation.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: The TBI won’t touch it This is hot and it’s in our lap.
dialogues.context: Enderby explains why the TBI won't take the case.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: And it’s not good, Lije. Every one of us stands the chance of being out of a job.
dialogues.context: Enderby warns of the potential consequences for the department.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Replace us all? Nuts. The trained men to do it with don’t exist.
dialogues.context: Baley dismisses the idea of replacing the department staff.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: R’s. They exist.
dialogues.context: Enderby suggests robots as replacements for human staff.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: What?
dialogues.context: Baley is surprised by Enderby's suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: R. Sammy is just a beginning. He runs errands. Others can patrol the expressways. Damn it man, I know the Spacers better than you do, and I know what they’re doing. There are R’s that can do your work and mine. We can be declassified. Don’t think differently. And at our age, to hit the labor pool …
dialogues.context: Enderby explains the potential for robots to replace human jobs.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: All right.
dialogues.context: Baley acknowledges the possibility of being replaced by robots.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Sorry, Lije.
dialogues.context: Enderby apologizes for the difficult situation.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: When did all this replacement business come up?
dialogues.context: Baley inquires about the timeline of robot replacements.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Look, you’re being naïve, Lije. It’s been happening all along. It’s been happening for twenty-five years, ever since the Spacers came. You know that. It’s just beginning to reach higher, that’s all. If we muff this case, it’s a big, long step toward the point where we can stop looking forward to collecting our pension-tab booklets. On the other hand, Lije, if we handle the matter well, it can shove that point far into the future. And it would be a particular break for you.
dialogues.context: Enderby explains the long-standing trend of robot replacements.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: For me?
dialogues.context: Baley questions how the situation could benefit him.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: You’ll be the operative in charge, Lije.
dialogues.context: Enderby offers Baley a leadership role in the investigation.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: I don’t rate it, Commissioner. I’m a C-5, that’s all.
dialogues.context: Baley expresses doubt about his qualifications for the role.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: You want a C-6 rating, don’t you?
dialogues.context: Enderby offers Baley a potential promotion.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: I want it. Sure. Why wouldn’t I? But what would I get if I couldn’t break the case?
dialogues.context: Baley considers the risks and rewards of the promotion.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Why wouldn’t you break it, Lije? You’re a good man. You’re one of the best we have.
dialogues.context: Enderby expresses confidence in Baley's abilities.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: But there are half a dozen men with higher ratings in my department section. Why should they be passed over?
dialogues.context: Baley questions why he is being chosen over others.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Two reasons. You’re not just another detective to me, Lije. We’re friends, too. I’m not forgetting we were in college together. Sometimes it may look as though I have forgotten, but that’s the fault of rating. I’m Commissioner, and you know what that means. But I’m still your friend and this is a tremendous chance for the right person. I want you to have it.
dialogues.context: Enderby explains his personal reasons for choosing Baley.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: That’s one reason.
dialogues.context: Baley acknowledges Enderby's first reason.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: The second reason is that I think you’re my friend. I need a favor.
dialogues.context: Enderby introduces a request for a favor.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: What sort of favor?
dialogues.context: Baley asks for details about the favor.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: I want you to take on a Spacer partner in this deal. That was the condition the Spacers made. They’ve agreed not to report the murder; they’ve agreed to leave the investigation in our hands. In return, they insist one of their own agents be in on the deal, the whole deal.
dialogues.context: Enderby explains the condition set by the Spacers.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: It sounds like they don’t trust us altogether.
dialogues.context: Baley comments on the Spacers' lack of trust.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Surely you see their point. If this is mishandled, a number of them will be in trouble with their own governments. I’ll give them the benefit of the doubt, Lije. I’m willing to believe they mean well.
dialogues.context: Enderby justifies the Spacers' condition.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: I’m sure they do, Commissioner. That’s the trouble with them.
dialogues.context: Baley expresses skepticism about the Spacers' intentions.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Are you willing to take on a Spacer partner, Lije?
dialogues.context: Enderby asks Baley to accept the Spacer partner.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: You’re asking that as a favor?
dialogues.context: Baley confirms the nature of the request.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m asking you to take the job with all the conditions the Spacers have set up.
dialogues.context: Enderby reiterates the conditions of the job.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: I’ll take a Spacer partner, Commissioner.
dialogues.context: Baley agrees to the condition.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Thanks, Lije. He’ll have to live with you.
dialogues.context: Enderby adds a further condition about the Spacer partner.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Oh, now, hold on.
dialogues.context: Baley protests the living arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: I know. I know. But you’ve got a large apartment, Lije. Three rooms. Only one child. You can put him up. He’ll be no trouble. No trouble at all. And it’s necessary.
dialogues.context: Enderby insists on the necessity of the arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Jessie won’t like it. I know that.
dialogues.context: Baley anticipates his wife's reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: You tell Jessie that if you do this for me, I’ll do what I can when this is all over to jump you a grade. C-7, Lije. C-7!
dialogues.context: Enderby offers further incentive for Baley to agree.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: All right, Commissioner, it’s a deal.
dialogues.context: Baley agrees to the arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: There’s something else?
dialogues.context: Baley senses there is more to discuss.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: One more item.
dialogues.context: Enderby confirms there is additional information.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Which is?
dialogues.context: Baley asks for the final piece of information.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: The name of your partner.
dialogues.context: Enderby reveals the identity of Baley's partner.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: What difference does that make?
dialogues.context: Baley questions the significance of the partner's name.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: The Spacers have peculiar ways. The partner they’re supplying isn’t – isn’t …
dialogues.context: Enderby hesitates to reveal the partner's nature.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Just a minute!
dialogues.context: Baley interrupts, sensing something significant.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: You’ve got to, Lije. You’ve got to. There’s no way out.
dialogues.context: Enderby insists on the necessity of the arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: Stay at my apartment? A thing like that?
dialogues.context: Baley is shocked by the arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: As a friend, please!
dialogues.context: Enderby appeals to Baley's friendship.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: No. No!
dialogues.context: Baley initially refuses the arrangement.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: Lije, I can’t trust anyone else in this. Do I have to spell it out for you? We’ve got to work with the Spacers. We’ve got to succeed, if we’re to keep the indemnity ships away from Earth. But we can’t succeed just any old way. You’ll be partnered with one of their R’s. If he breaks the case, if he can report that we’re incompetent, we’re ruined, anyway. We, as a department. You see that, don’t you? So you’ve got a delicate job on your hands. You’ve got to work with him, but see to it that you solve the case and not he. Understand?
dialogues.context: Enderby explains the stakes and the delicate nature of the task.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: You mean co-operate with him 100 per cent, except that I cut his throat? Pat him on the back with a knife in my hand?
dialogues.context: Baley summarizes the difficult balancing act required.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: What else can we do? There’s no other way out.
dialogues.context: Enderby affirms the necessity of the approach.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: I don’t know what Jessie will say.
dialogues.context: Baley expresses concern about his wife's reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: I’ll talk to her, if you want me to.
dialogues.context: Enderby offers to speak with Baley's wife.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: No, Commissioner.
dialogues.context: Baley declines Enderby's offer.

dialogues.speaker: Elijah 'Lije' Baley
dialogues.text: What’s my partner’s name?
dialogues.context: Baley asks for the name of his partner.

dialogues.speaker: Julius Enderby
dialogues.text: R. Daneel Olivaw.
